newsitem.title: GERMANY: German publisher of Stern magazine dies.
newsitem.headline: German publisher of Stern magazine dies.

text.p: Henri Nannen, founder and long-time publisher of Germany's biggest-selling magazine Stern, died on Sunday after a long battle with cancer, a spokesman for the magazine said. He was 82.
One of the country's most influential journalists and a noted art collector, Nannen launched the weekly illustrated Stern amid the rubble of post-war Germany in 1948.
Its colourful focus on issues that affected ordinary people helped it to become at one point the magazine with the largest circulation in Europe.
Whether publishing articles critical of the government or church, Stern tapped the mood of nation and often triggered national discussions with its cover stories.
It also sometimes drew the ire of the occupying Western Allies in Germany, which on several occasions confiscated issues of the magazine in the 1940s and 1950s.
The magazine's reputation was badly tarnished in 1983, three years after Nannen retired as editor-in-chief, when it published what turned out to be the bogus "Hitler Diaries".
Nannen, who was a member of the magazine's board of directors at the time, accepted blame for the fiasco even though he was no longer running the magazine.
The scandal cost the magazine much of its credibility and eroded its circulation for several years.
"I will always have to live with the fact that I failed here politically and journalistically," Nannen said.
A Stern reporter was duped by a Stuttgart forger named Konrad Kujau in 1983 into believing he had "found" dozens of diaries secretly written by Nazi leader Adolf Hitler.
But shortly after the magazine published what it called "the biggest journalistic coup of the post-war era" they were proved to be forgeries. Several Stern editors resigned in disgrace.
Stern reporter Gerd Heidemann and the forger Kujau were each sentenced to prison terms of more than four years.

Nannen was born on December 25, 1913 in Emden, north Germany. He studied art history at the University of Munich and worked briefly in 1938 as a journalist for an art magazine known as "Art in a Germany renewed by the Fuehrer."
But he was dismissed after writing an article about a Jewish author. During World War Two Nannen served as an officer in the Luftwaffe.
After the war, he started a newspaper in 1946 in Hanover before launching Stern, first known as "Zickzack", in 1948.
After retiring as editor-in-chief of Stern, Nannen turned his focus to art. He opened an art gallery in Emden in 1986.
